sn7.20:1.2: Then a begging brahmin went up to the Buddha, and exchanged greetings with him.
sn7.20:1.3: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side and said to the Buddha,
sn7.20:1.4: “Master Gotama, both you and I are beggars. What, then, is the difference between us?”
sn7.20:2.3: One who has undertaken domestic duties
sn7.20:2.4: has not yet become a mendicant.
sn7.20:3.1: But one living a spiritual life
sn7.20:3.2: who has banished both merit and evil,
sn7.20:3.3: and wanders having assessed the world,
sn7.20:3.4: is said to be a mendicant.”
sn7.20:4.1: When he had spoken, the begging brahmin said to the Buddha,
sn7.20:4.3: From this day forth, may Master Gotama remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”
